He also met [[Horace Holley (Bahá'í)|Horace Holley]] there.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last= Kazemzadeh |first= Firuz| authorlink= Firuz Kazemzadeh |encyclopedia= Bahá’í Encyclopedia Project |title= 'Abdu'l-Bahá 'Abbás (1844–1921) |year= 2009 |publisher= National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá’ís of the United States |location= Evanston, IL |url= http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=81:abdul-baha-abbas-1844-1921&catid=36:administrationinstitutions#personal | accessdate = 14 March 2010 | ref = harv |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131017150626/http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=81:abdul-baha-abbas-1844-1921&catid=36:administrationinstitutions |archivedate= 17 October 2013 }}</ref> While in Thonon, `Abdu'l-Bahá met [[Mass'oud Mirza Zell-e Soltan]], who had asked to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá. Soltan, who had ordered the execution of [[Núrayn-i-Nayyirayn|King and Beloved of martyrs]], was the eldest grandson of [[Naser al-Din Shah Qajar]] who had ordered the [[Execution of the Báb]] himself. Thompson, an American Bahá'í who had also come to visit `Abdu'l-Bahá, shared comments of Hippolyte who heard Soltan's stammering apology for past wrongs. `Abdu'l-Bahá embraced him and invited his sons to lunch.<ref name="JT">{{harvnb|Thompson|Gail|1983|pp=147–223}}</ref> Thus Bahram Mirza Sardar Mass'oud and [[Akbar Mass’oud]], another grandson of Naser al-Din Shah Qajar, met with the Bahá'ís, and apparently Akbar was greatly affected by meeting `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref>{{harvnb|Honnold|2010|pp=51–52}}</ref>
===Great Britain=== On 3 September `Abdu'l-Bahá left the shores of Lake Geneva travelling towards [[London]] where he arrived on 4 September; he would stay in London until 23 September. While in London `Abdu'l-Bahá stayed at a residence of [[Lady Blomfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.btinternet.com/~iain.s.palin/heritage/blmem.htm|title=UK Bahá'í Heritage Site-A memorial to Lady Blomfield|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020144718/http://www.btinternet.com/~iain.s.palin/heritage/blmem.htm|archivedate=20 October 2012}} by Rob Weinberg and originally published in ''Bahá'í Journal'' UK</ref> On the first few days in London `Abdu'l-Bahá was interviewed by the editor of the ''Christian Commonwealth'', a weekly newspaper devoted to a liberal Christian theology.<ref name="SoW0210" /><ref>{{harvnb|Canney|1921|p=102}}</ref> The editor was also present at a meeting of the Reverend [[Reginald John Campbell]] and `Abdu'l-Bahá and wrote about the meeting in the 13 September edition of the ''Christian Commonwealth'' and the reprinted in the [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West Bahá'í magazine]].<ref name="SoW0210">{{cite journal | last = True | first = Corinne | title = Towards Spiritual Unity | journal = Star of the West | volume = 02 | issue = 10–11 |pages=2, 4–7 | publisher = Bahá'í News Service | location = Chicago, USA | date = 27 September 1911 | url = http://www.bahai-education.org/star/ | editor-last = Windust | editor-first = Albert R | editor2-last = Buikema | editor2-first = Gertrude | accessdate = 14 March 2010 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111107020747/http://bahai-education.org:80/star/ | archivedate = 7 November 2011 }}</ref> After the meeting, the Reverend Reginald John Campbell asked `Abdu'l-Bahá to speak at [[City Temple (London)|City Temple]].
Later in the month `Abdu'l-Bahá took a trip to [[Byfleet]] near Surrey where he visited Alice Buckton and Anett Schepel at their home.<ref name="Chosen" /><ref name="ABL">{{harvnb|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1911b}}</ref><ref name="buckhorn">{{cite web | title = Alice Mary Buckton | work = History, genealogical data and interesting facts about the Buckton family | publisher = Buckton Family | year = 2010 | url =http://bucktonfamily.co.uk/interesting-bucktons/alice-mary-buckton.html | accessdate = 14 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100618165917/http://bucktonfamily.co.uk:80/interesting-bucktons/alice-mary-buckton.html | archivedate = 18 June 2010 }}</ref> On the evening of 10 September he gave his first public talk in the Occident at [[City Temple (London)|City Temple]]<ref name="ABL" /> The English translation was read by [[Wellesley Tudor Pole]]<ref name="Chosen" /> and the talk was printed in the ''Christian Commonwealth'' newspaper on 13 September.
On 17 September, at the invitation of [[Albert Basil Orme Wilberforce|Albert Wilberforce]], Archdeacon of Westminster, he addressed the congregation of [[St John's Chapel, London|Saint John the Divine]], in [[Westminster]].<ref name="Chosen" /> He spoke on the subject of the kingdoms of mineral, vegetable, animal, humanity, and the [[Manifestation of God|Manifestations of God]] beneath God;<ref name="ABL" /> Albert Wilberforce read the English translation himself.<ref name="Chosen" /> On the 28th `Abdu'l-Bahá returned to Byfleet again visiting Buckhorn and Schepel.<ref name="ABL" /><ref name="buckhorn" /> He visited [[Bristol]] on the 23rd–25th for several receptions and meetings though less public. On one such meeting he mentioned "When a thought of war enters your mind, suppress it, and plant in its stead a positive thought of peace."<ref name="Chosen" /> On the 30th he spoke to a [[Theosophical Society]] meeting with [[Annie Besant]], [[Alfred Percy Sinnett]], [[Eric Hammond]],<ref name="Chosen" /> who later published a volume on the religion in 1909.<ref>{{cite book | last = trans. Hammond | first = Eric | editor-last = Cranmer-Byng | editor-first = L. | editor2-last = Kapadia | editor2-first = SA | title = Wisdom of the East; The splendour of God; being extracts from the sacred writings of the Bahais | publisher = John Murray, Albamarle St, | date = June 1909 | location = London, UK| page = 124 | url = https://archive.org/stream/splendourofgodbe00hammrich#page/n5/mode/2up | isbn =| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121108180837/https://archive.org/stream/splendourofgodbe00hammrich | archivedate = 8 November 2012 }}</ref> Back in London Alice Buckton visited Abdu'l-Bahá once again, and he went to [[Church House (Church of England)|Church House, Westminster]] to see a Christmas [[mystery play]] titled ''Eager Heart'' that she had written.<ref name="Chosen" />
From 23 to 25 September, `Abdu'l-Bahá went to [[Bristol]] where he met with many leading individuals including [[David Graham Pole]], [[Claude Montefiore]], [[Alexander Whyte]], [[Evelyn Byng, Viscountess Byng of Vimy|Lady Evelyn Moreton]] among others.<ref name="Chosen" /> Rev. Peter Z. Easton, a Presbyterian in the [[Synod of the Northeast]] in New York who was stationed in [[Tabriz]], Iran from 1873 to 1880, didn't have an appointment to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref>{{cite web | title = Minutes of the ... annual session of the Synod of New York | work = | publisher =Presbyterian in the Synod of the Northeast | date = 29 March 1914 | url = https://archive.org/stream/minutesofannuals1914pres/minutesofannuals1914pres_djvu.txt | accessdate = 14 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121108180843/https://archive.org/stream/minutesofannuals1914pres/minutesofannuals1914pres_djvu.txt| archivedate = 8 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | editor-last = Rev. Simpson | editor-first = Albert B | editor2-last = Rev. Smith | editor2-first = Eugene R. | title = Persia Mission of the Presbytrian Church, Independent Mission Work In Persia and the Caucasus | journal = The Gospel in All Lands | volume = 04 | issue = 4 | pages = 175–177 | publisher = Bible House | location = New York | date = October 1881 | url =http://www.cmalliance.org/resources/archives/downloads/gospel-in-all-lands/gospel-in-all-lands-1881-10.pdf | accessdate = 14 March 2010 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120229144642/http://www.cmalliance.org/resources/archives/downloads/gospel-in-all-lands/gospel-in-all-lands-1881-10.pdf | archivedate = 29 February 2012 }}</ref> Easton attempted to meet and challenge `Abdu'l-Bahá and in his actions made those around him uncomfortable; `Abdu'l-Bahá withdrew him to a private conversation and then he left. Later he printed a polemic attack on the religion, ''Bahaism — A Warning'', in the ''Evangelical Christendom'' newspaper of London (September–October 1911 edition.)<ref>{{cite book |author=Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl Gulpáygání | origyear = 1912 |year=1998 |title=The Brilliant Proof |location=Los Angeles | publisher=Kalimát Press |url= http://bahai-library.com/books/brilliant.proof/appendix.html#Heading11 | page = APPENDIX Bahaism – A Warning, by Peter Z. Easton |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406144001/http://bahai-library.com/books/brilliant.proof/appendix.html |archivedate=6 April 2013 }}</ref> The polemic was later responded to by [[Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl]] in his book ''The Brilliant Proof'' written in December 1911.<ref>''Burhan-i-Lami`'' (The Brilliant Proof): Published, along with an English translation, in Chicago in 1912, the paper responds to a Christian clergyman's questions. Republished as {{cite book |author=Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl Gulpáygání | origyear = 1912 |year=1998 |title=The Brilliant Proof |location=Los Angeles | publisher=Kalimát Press |url=http://bahai-library.com/gulpaygani_brilliant_proof|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408033508/http://bahai-library.com/gulpaygani_brilliant_proof |archivedate=8 April 2013 }}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá returned to London on 25 September, and a pastor of a Congregational church in the east end of London invited him to give an address on the following Sunday evening.<ref name="Chosen" /> `Abdu'l-Bahá also visited to [[Oxford University]] where he met the [[Higher criticism|higher Bible critic]], Dr. [[Thomas Kelly Cheyne]]. Though ill, `Abdu'l-Bahá embraced him and praised his life's work.<ref name="Chosen" /><ref>{{cite web | last = Lambden| first = Stephen N.| title = Thomas Kelly Cheyne (1841-1915), Biblical Scholar and Bahá'í | work = | publisher = Hurqalya Publications | date = | url =http://www.hurqalya.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/baha'i%20encyclopedia/thomas_kelly_cheyne.htm | accessdate = 14 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120401032505/http://www.hurqalya.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/baha'i%20encyclopedia/thomas_kelly_cheyne.htm| archivedate = 1 April 2012}}</ref> News of his activity in Britain was covered in New Zealand in a couple publications.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=o9cqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IGYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2769%2C303720|title=Persian Prophet of Bahaism a London Society Cult|date=1 October 1911|newspaper =The Pittsburg Gazette Times|pages=2, Second section|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Bahaism. A New Religion from Persia "Prophet's" visit to London | newspaper = Grey River Argus | location = New Zealand | page = 1 | date = 6 November 1911 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=GRA19111106.2.5 | accessdate = 15 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120929054809/http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=GRA19111106.2.5 | archivedate = 29 September 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Bahaism. A New Religion from Persia "Prophet's" visit to London | newspaper = Poverty Bay Herald | location = New Zealand | page = 1 | date = 21 October 1911 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=PBH19111021.2.65 | accessdate = 15 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120929054840/http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=PBH19111021.2.65 | archivedate = 29 September 2012 }}</ref>
[[Ezra Pound]] met with him about the end of September, later explaining to [[Margaret Craven (writer)|Margaret Craven]] that Pound approached him like "an inquisition… and came away feeling that questions would been an impertinence…."<ref name="EP-Moody">{{cite book| last = Moody| first = A. David| title = Ezra Pound Poet I The Young Genius 1885-1920| url = https://books.google.com/?id=bryrngEACAAJ&pg=PA159| accessdate = 12 April 2013| date = 11 October 2007| publisher = Oxford University Press| isbn = 978-0-19-921557-7| page = 159 }}</ref> <blockquote>The whole point is that they have ''done'' instead of talking, and a persian movement for religious unity that claims the feminine soul equal to the male… is worth while."<ref name="EP-Moody"/></blockquote>
On 1 October 1911, he returned to Bristol to perform a wedding of Bahá'ís who had traveled from Persia and who brought humble gifts as well.<ref name="Chosen" /><ref name="ABL" /> On 3 October `Abdu'l-Bahá left London for [[Paris]], France.<ref name="smith" />
===France=== `Abdu'l-Bahá stayed in Paris for nine weeks, during which time he stayed at a residence at 4 Avenue de Camoens, and during his time there he was helped by Mr. Dreyfus-Barney and his wife, along with [[Lady Blomfield]] who had come from London. `Abdu'l-Bahá's first talk in Paris was on 16 October,<ref name="Oct16" /> and later that same day guests gathered in a poor quarter outside Paris at a home for orphans by Mr and Mrs. Ponsonaille which was much praised by `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Beede | first = Alice R.| title = A Glimpse of Abdul-Baha in Paris | journal = Star of the West | volume = 02 | issue = 18 |pages=6, 7, 12 | date = 7 February 1912 | publisher = Bahá'í News Service | location = Chicago, USA | editor-last = Windust | editor-first = Albert R | editor2-last = Buikema | editor2-first = Gertrude | url =http://bahai-library.com/beede_glimpse_abdulbaha_paris | accessdate = 15 April 2010 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130407183915/http://bahai-library.com/beede_glimpse_abdulbaha_paris | archivedate = 7 April 2013 }}</ref>
From almost every day from 16 October to 26 November he gives talks.<ref name="Oct16">{{harvnb|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1995|pp=15–17}}</ref><ref name="abp">{{harvnb|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1995|pp=119–123}}</ref> On a few of the days, he gave more than one talk. The book [[Paris Talks]], part I, records transcripts of `Abdu'l-Bahá's talks while he was in Paris for the first time. The substance of the volume is from notes [[Lady Blomfield|Sara Louisa Blomfield]],<ref>{{cite news | title = Memorial to a shining star | newspaper = Bahá'í International News Service | publisher = Bahá’í International Community | date = 10 August 2003 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/237 | accessdate = 15 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130123161954/http://news.bahai.org/story/237 | archivedate = 23 January 2013 }}</ref> her two daughters and a friend.<ref>{{cite book | last = Abdu'l-Bahá | first = | authorlink = Abdu'l-Bahá | editor=Lady Blomfield | title = Talks by Abdul Baha Given in Paris | publisher = G. Bell and Sons, LTD | year = 1916 | page = 5 | url = https://archive.org/details/talksbyabdulbaha029093mbp| isbn = }}</ref> While most of his talks were held at his residence, he also gave talks at the [[Theosophical Society]] headquarters, at [[L'Alliance Spiritaliste]], and on 26 November he spoke at [[Charles Wagner]]'s church ''Foyer de l-Ame''.<ref name="abp" /> He also met with various people including Muhammad ibn `Abdu'l-Vahhad-i Qazvini and Seyyed [[Hasan Taqizadeh]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Taqizadeh | first = Hasan | author2 = Muhammad ibn `Abdu'l-Vahhad-i Qazvini | title = `Abdu'l-Baha Meeting with Two Prominent Iranians | work = Published academic articles and papers | publisher = Bahai Academic Library |origyear = 1949 | year = 1998 | url = http://bahai-library.com/qazvini_abdulbaha_prominent_iranians | accessdate = 15 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140404125447/http://bahai-library.com/qazvini_abdulbaha_prominent_iranians | archivedate = 4 April 2014 }}</ref> It was during one of the meetings with Taqizadeh that `Abdu'l-Bahá personally first spoke on a [[History of the telephone|telephone]].
On 2 December 1911 `Abdu'l-Bahá left France, returning to Egypt.<ref name="Balyuzi" />
==Trip to North America== [[File:Railroads of the United States in 1918 - Project Gutenberg eText 16960.png|thumb|Railroads of the United States in 1918 - Project Gutenberg eText 16960]] In the following year, `Abdu'l-Bahá undertook a much more extensive journey to the United States and [[Canada]], ultimately visiting some 40 cities, to once again spread his father's teachings.<ref>{{harvnb|Hatcher|Martin|2002|pg=57-59}}</ref> He arrived in New York City on 11 April 1912. While he spent most of his time in New York, he visited many cities on the east coast. Then in August he started a more extensive journey across to the West coast before starting to return east at the end of October. On 5 December 1912 he set sail back to Europe.<ref name="b_end" /> Several people, including `Abdu'l-Bahá himself, Dr. Allan L. Ward, author of ''239 Days''', and critic Samuel Graham Wilson have taken note of the uniqueness of this trip.<ref>{{harvnb|Ward|1979|p=ix, 10}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Wilson|1915|pp=263–286}}</ref> Ward wrote: "... never before during the formative years of a religion has a figure of like stature made a journey of such magnitude in a setting so different from that of His native land." Wilson stated: "But Abdul Baha, except for Hindu Swamis, was the first Asiatic revelator America has received. Its hospitality showed up well. The public and press neither stoned the "prophet" nor caricatured him but looked with kindly eye upon the grave old man, in flowing oriental robes and white turban, with waving hoary hair and long white beard."
During his nine months on the continent, he met with [[David Starr Jordan]], president of Stanford University; Rabbi [[Stephen Samuel Wise]] of New York City; the inventor [[Alexander Graham Bell]]; [[Jane Addams]], the noted social worker; the Indian poet [[Bahá'í Faith and Rabindranath Tagore|Rabindranath Tagore]], who was touring America at the time;<ref name = "terry">Terry, Peter (1992, 2015) ''[https://bahai-library.com/terry_tagore_encounters_bahais Rabindranath Tagore: Some Encounters with Bahá'ís]''.</ref> [[Herbert Putnam]], Librarian of Congress; the industrialist and humanitarian [[Andrew Carnegie]]; [[Samuel Gompers]], president of the American Federation of Labor; the Arctic explorer Admiral [[Robert Peary]]; as well as hundreds of American and Canadian Bahá’ís, recent converts to the religion.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last= Kazemzadeh |first= Firuz |encyclopedia= Bahá’í Encyclopedia Project |title= 'Abdu'l-Bahá 'Abbás (1844–1921) |year= 2009 |publisher= National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá’ís of the United States |location= Evanston, IL |url= http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?view=article&catid=36%3Aadministrationinstitutions&id=81%3Aabdul-baha-abbas-1844-1921&option=com_content&Itemid=74 | ref = harv }}</ref>
A large number of memoirs cover this period<ref group="nb">Transcripts of many talks given by `Abdu'l-Bahá in the US and Canada can be found in:
* {{cite book| author = 'Abdu’l-Bahá| title = The Promulgation of Universal Peace| url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PUP/| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131008230458/http://reference.bahai.org:80/en/t/ab/PUP/| archivedate = 8 October 2013| edition = 2nd| origyear = 1922| year = 1982| publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust| isbn = 978-0-87743-172-5| page = 513 }}
Other memoirs covering the period include:
* {{cite book| last = Brown| first = Ramona Allen| title = Memories of `Abdu'l-Bahá; Recollections of the Early Days of the Bahá'í Faith in California| year = 1980| publisher = US Bahá'í Publishing Trust| location = US| isbn = 978-0-87743-139-8 }} * {{cite book| last = Gail| first = Marzieh| title = Arches of the Years| url = http://bahairesearch.com/english/Baha'i/Baha'i_Studies/Marzieh_Gail/Arches_of_the_Years.aspx| year = 1991| publisher = George Ronald Publisher Ltd| isbn = 978-0-85398-325-5| pages = Chapters: 15 to 18 }} * {{cite book| last = Ives| first = Howard Colby| title = Portals to Freedom| url = https://books.google.com/?id=L1jYAAAAMAAJ| origyear = 1937| year = 1983| publisher = George Ronald| location = UK| isbn = 978-0-85398-013-1 }} * {{cite book| last = Parsons| first = Agnes| editor-last = Hollinger| editor-first = Richard| title = `Abdu'l-Bahá in America; Agnes Parsons' Diary| url = https://books.google.com/?id=C2r6CO1qqL4C&pg=PA3| year = 1996| publisher = Kalimat Press| location = US| isbn = 978-0-933770-91-1 }} * {{cite book| last = Thompson| first = Juliet| title = The diary of Juliet Thompson| url = http://bahai-library.com/books/thompson/4.html| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130404182120/http://bahai-library.com/books/thompson/4.html| archivedate = 4 April 2013| year = 1983| publisher = Kalimat Press| isbn = 978-0-933770-27-0| pages = ; Chapter ''`Abdu'l–Bahá in America''| author2 = Marzieh Gail }} * {{cite book| last = Zarqānī| first = Maḥmūd.| title = Mahmúd's Diary Chronicling `Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey to America| url = http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131228031741/http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary| archivedate = 28 December 2013| origyear = 1913| year = 1998| publisher = George Ronald| location = Oxford, UK| isbn = 978-0-85398-418-4 }}
Special mention should note the book ''239 Days; `Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey in America '' by Dr. Allan L. Ward which brings together various references including newspapers, magazines, and memoirs for a detailed review of this period. The book builds on Ward's 1960 PhD dissertation.
* {{cite book| last = Dr. Ward| first = Allan L.| title = 239 Days; `Abdu'-Bahá's Journey in America| year = 1979| publisher = US Bahá'í Publishing Trust| isbn = 978-0-87743-129-9 }} * {{cite web | last = Ward | first = Allan L. | title = An historical study of the North American speaking tour of ʻAbduʼl-Bahá and a rhetorical analysis of his addresses | work = University Libraries ALICE Online Catalog | publisher = Ohio University Libraries (Athens) | year = 1960 | url = http://alice.library.ohiou.edu/record=b2351900~S7 | accessdate = 19 March 2010}}
Ward also presented at the 5th Annual Canadian ''Association for Bahá'í Studies'' with a talk titled "`Abdu'l-Bahá and the American Press" and also published a number of essays in World Order Magazine, a Bahá'í serial, at least 3 times from 1968 to 1972.
* {{cite magazine| title = Hand of Cause Robarts present at Canadian Association's fifth annual conference |magazine= Bahá'í News | date = October 1980 | page = 12 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | issue = 515| ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140512094900/http://teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | archivedate = 12 May 2014 }} * {{cite web | title = Analysis of Topics Published in World Order | work = Bahá'í Bibliography | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = September 2003 | url = http://bahai-library.com/topics_world_order | accessdate = 27 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140404125027/http://bahai-library.com/topics_world_order | archivedate = 4 April 2014 }}</ref> as well as a wide array of newspaper stories.<ref>{{cite web| title = News Clips| work = `Abdu'l-Bahá in America • 1912-2012 | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá’ís of the United States | year = 2011 | url = http://centenary.bahai.us/news| accessdate = 2 April 2012| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131106175955/http://centenary.bahai.us/news| archivedate = 6 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = Egea | first = Amin | title = The Travels of 'Abdu'l-Bahá and their Impact on the Press|journal = Lights of Irfan | volume = 12 | pages = 1–25 | publisher = Haj Mehdi Armand Colloquium | location = Wilmette, IL. | year = 2011 | url = http://bahai-library.com/?id=4900 | accessdate =2 April 2012 | ref = harv }}</ref>
===On the RMS Cedric=== `Abdu'l-Bahá boarded the [[RMS Cedric]] in [[Alexandria, Egypt]] bound for [[Naples]] on 25 March 1912.<ref name="smith" /> Others with him included [[Shoghi Effendi]], Asadu'lláh-i-Qumí, Dr Amínu'lláh Faríd, Mírzá Munír-i-Zayn, Áqá Khusraw, and Mahmúd-i-Zarqání.<ref name="Mahmud">{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998}}</ref> During the voyage a member of the [[Unitarianism|Unitarians]] onboard requested if `Abdu'l-Bahá would send a message to them. He replied with a message announcing "… Glad tidings, glad tidings, the Herald of the Kingdom has raised His voice."<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|p=17}}</ref> Through several conversations it was arranged by several passengers that he address a larger audience on the ship.<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|p=20}}</ref> The ship arrived in Naples harbour on 28 March 1912,<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=21–22}}</ref> and on the next day several Bahá'ís from America and Britain boarded the ship. `Abdu'l-Bahá and his group did not disembark for fear of being confused with Turks during the ongoing [[Italo-Turkish War]]. Shoghi Effendi and two others were refused further passage by reason of a minor illness and were taken ashore. Though all were not convinced of the sincerity of the diagnosis and some presumed it was ill will against the voyagers as if they were Turkish.<ref name="smith" />
The American Bahá'í community had sent thousands of dollars urging `Abdu'l-Bahá to leave the Cedric in Italy and travel to England to sail on the maiden voyage of the [[RMS Titanic]]. Instead he returned the money for charity and continued the voyage on the Cedric.<ref name="Lacroix ">{{harvnb|Lacroix-Hopson|1987}}</ref> From Naples, the group sailed on to New York — the group included `Abdu'l-Bahá, Asadu'lláh-i-Qumí, Dr Amínu'lláh Faríd, Mahmúd-i-Zarqání, Mr and Mrs Percy Woodcock and their daughter from Canada, Mr and Mrs Austin from Denver, Colorado, and Miss Louisa Mathew.<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=22–23}}</ref> Other notables aboard included at least two Italian embassy officials; note `Abdu'l-Bahá was listed as an "author" on immigration paperwork.<ref>{{cite web | last = Poirier | first = Brent | title = `Abdu'l-Bahá's Immigration Record | work = | publisher = | year = 2002 | url = http://arrivals.netfirms.com/cedric.htm | accessdate = 27 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714164837/http://arrivals.netfirms.com/cedric.htm| archivedate = 14 July 2011}}</ref> They passed [[Gibraltar]] on 3 April onward to New York.<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=27–28}}</ref> Many letters and telegrams were sent and received during the voyage as well as various tablets written.
===New England=== The SS Cedric arrived in [[New York City|New York]] harbour on the morning of 11 April and telegrams were sent and received from Bahá'í local spiritual assemblies to announce his safe arrival while the passengers were processed for quarantine.<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=34–35}}</ref> Bahá'ís who had gathered at the port were generally sent to gather at a home where `Abdu'l-Bahá was to visit later. Reporters interviewed him while he was on board and he elaborated on the trip and his goals. However a few Bahá'ís, including Marjorie Morten, Rhoda Nichols and [[Juliet Thompson]], hid themselves to catch a glimpse of `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref>{{harvnb|Thompson|Gail|1983|pp=233–234}}</ref> His arrival in New York was covered by various different newspapers including the [[New York Tribune]]<ref>{{cite news | title = Persian Prophet Here; Abdul Baha Abbas Comes to Preach Universal Peace | newspaper = New York Tribune |page=13 (3rd column) | publisher = | date = 12 April 1912| url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-04-12/ed-1/seq-13/| accessdate = 29 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121006091040/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-04-12/ed-1/seq-13/| archivedate = 6 October 2012}}</ref> and the [[Washington Post]].<ref>{{cite news | title = In Exile for 50 Years' Bahai Leader Comes to New York to Urge World Peace; He favors woman suffrage | newspaper = Washington Post | page = 4 (4th column) (requires registration) | date = 11 April 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=5507179&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0&fpo=False | accessdate = 30 April 2010}}</ref>
While in New York he stayed at [[The Ansonia]] hotel.<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|p=37}}</ref> Several blocks to the north west of the hotel was the residence of Edward B. Kinney, where `Abdu'l-Bahá held his first meeting with the American Bahá'ís;<ref>{{harvnb|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1912}}</ref> his next talk was at given at [[Howard MacNutt]]'s residence. From 11 April until 25 April he gave at least one talk a day and most mornings and afternoons were spent meeting often one by one with visitors coming to his residence.<ref name="Mahmud" /><ref name="Thompson 1983">{{harvnb|Thompson|Gail|1983}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Ward|1979}}</ref> During `Abdu'l-Bahá's time in New York, [[Lua Getsinger]] helped correspond with various Bahá'ís about `Abdu'l-Bahá's plans as they evolved.<ref name="Lua">{{harvnb|Metelmann|1997|pp=150–184}}</ref>
Rev. [[Percy Stickney Grant]], through association with [[Juliet Thompson]], invited `Abdu'l-Bahá to speak at [[Church of the Ascension, Episcopal (Manhattan)|Church of the Ascension]] on the evening of 14 April.<ref name="Thompson 1983" /> The event was covered by the New York Times,<ref>{{cite news | title = `Abdu'l-Baha prays in Ascension Church | newspaper = New York Times | publisher = | date = 15 April 1912 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/04/15/104895581.pdf | accessdate = 29 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216001139/https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/04/15/104895581.pdf| archivedate = 16 December 2013}}</ref> the ''[[New York Tribune]]'',<ref>{{cite news | title = Abbul Baha Preaches; Head of Bahai Movement Says All shall be Brothers Some Day | newspaper = New York Tribune |page=3 (3rd column) | publisher = | date = 15 April 1912| url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-04-15/ed-1/seq-3/ | accessdate = 15 December 2013| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216000536/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-04-15/ed-1/seq-3/| archivedate = 16 December 2013}}</ref> and the ''Washington Post''.<ref>{{cite news | title = Bahai Leader in Pulpit; Abdul Baha Abbas Preaches to Fashionable Congregation; Message of World Peace Voiced by Persian Philosopher in Fifth Avenue Church | newspaper = Washington Post | page = 4 (4th column) (registration required) | date = 15 April 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=5507997&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=2&currentPage=0&fpo=False | accessdate = 30 April 2010}}</ref> The event caused a stir because, while there were rules in the Episcopal Church Canon forbidding someone of another ordination from preaching from the pulpit without the consent of the bishop, there was no provision against a non-ordained person offering prayer in the [[chancel]].<ref>{{harvnb|Ward|1979|p=23}}</ref>
Mary Williams, also known as [[Kate Carew]], known for her caricatures,<ref>{{cite web | last = Schmidt | first = Barbara | title = KATE CAREW, "The Only Woman Caricaturist" | work = Special Features | url = http://www.twainquotes.com/interviews/confessions.html | accessdate = 16 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130121151735/http://www.twainquotes.com/interviews/confessions.html | archivedate = 21 January 2013 }}</ref> was among those who visited `Abdu'l-Bahá and travelled with him for a number of days. On 16 April, with Mary Williams still travelling with him, `Abdu'l-Bahá visited the [[Bowery]].<ref name="Carew">{{cite news | last = Williams | first = Mary | authorlink = Kate Carew | title = Abdul Baha Talks to Kate Carew of Things Spiritual and Mundane | newspaper = New York Tribune | date = 5 May 1912 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-05-05/ed-1/seq-17.pdf | accessdate = 31 August 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121011194440/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-05-05/ed-1/seq-17.pdf | archivedate = 11 October 2012 }}</ref> Mary Williams noted that she was impressed with `Abdu'l-Bahá's generosity of spirit in bringing people of social standing to the Bowery as well as that he then gave money to the poor.<ref name="Lacroix " /><ref name="Carew" /><ref>{{harvnb|Ward|1979|pp=27–35}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Free Money on Bowery; Abdul Baha Visits Mission and Distributes Quarters | newspaper = New York Tribune | page = 16 | publisher = | date = 20 April 1912 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-04-20/ed-1/seq-16/ | accessdate = 29 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121006091525/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-04-20/ed-1/seq-16/| archivedate = 6 October 2012}}</ref> Some boys were reported to heckle the event but were invited afterwards for a personal meeting. At this meeting, after greeting all the boys, `Abdu'l-Bahá singled out an African-American boy and compared him to a black rose as well as rich chocolate.<ref>{{harvnb|Ives|1983|pp=63–67}}</ref>
In Boston newspaper reporters asked `Abdu'l-Bahá why he had come to America, and he stated that he had come to participate in conferences on peace and that just giving warning messages is not enough.<ref name="b_p232">{{harvnb|Balyuzi|2001|p=232}}</ref> A full page summary of the religion was printed in the New York Times.<ref>{{cite news | title = A Message from Abdul Baha, Head of the Bahais | newspaper = New York Times | publisher = | date = 21 April 1912 | url =https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/04/21/100583140.pdf | accessdate = 29 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121110005705/https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/04/21/100583140.pdf| archivedate = 10 November 2012}}</ref> A booklet on the religion was published late April.<ref>{{cite news | title = Boston Letter; A Continuous issue of Books Planned by its Publishers; Bahaism | newspaper = New York Times | publisher = | date = 28 April 1912 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/04/28/100362517.pdf | accessdate = 29 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121110005714/https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/04/28/100362517.pdf| archivedate = 10 November 2012}}</ref>
On 20 April `Abdu'l-Bahá left New York and travelled to [[Washington D.C.]] where he stayed until 28 April. While in Washington D.C. a number of meetings and notable events took place. On 23 April `Abdu'l-Bahá attended several events;<ref>{{harvnb|Parsons|1996|pp=23–26}}</ref> first he spoke at [[Howard University]] to over 1000 students, faculty, administrators and visitors — an event commemorated in 2009.<ref>{{cite web | last = Musta | first = Lex | title = Get on the Bus for a Spiritual Journey through DC and Baha'i History | work = The News| publisher = Bahai Faith, Washington DC | date = 25 March 2009 | url =http://www.dcbahai.org/news-and-events/65-spiritual-journey-through-dc-and-bahai-history | accessdate = 27 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120517063028/http://www.dcbahai.org:80/news-and-events/65-spiritual-journey-through-dc-and-bahai-history | archivedate = 17 May 2012 }}</ref> Then he attended a reception by the Persian Charg-de-Affairs and the Turkish Ambassador;<ref name="Gregory">{{harvnb|Morrison|1982|pp=50–62}}</ref> at this reception `Abdu'l-Bahá moved the place-names such that the only African-American present, [[Louis George Gregory]], was seated at the head of the table next to himself.<ref name="Gregory" /><ref>{{harvnb|Ward|1979|pp=40–41}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Parsons|1996|pp=31–34}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Thompson|Gail|1983|pp=269–70}}</ref> `Abdu'l-Bahá also welcomed [[William Sulzer]], then a Democratic Congressman and later Governor from New York, as well as [[Champ Clark]], then Speaker of the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite web | last =Menon | first = Jonathan | title =At 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue | work =239 Days in America - a Social Media Documentary | publisher = | date =27 April 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/04/27/at-1600-pennsylvania-avenue/ | accessdate = 19 June 2014}}
Note Sulzer would go on to write expansively of the Baha'i Faith as he understood it: * {{cite news | last =Sulzer | first =William | title =What is Bahaism? | newspaper =The Broad Ax | location =Salt Lake City, Utah | page =2 | date =14 February 1920 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/650419/1920_feb_14_what_is_bahaism_photo_of/ | accessdate = 19 June 2014}} * {{cite news | title =William Sulzer will speak… | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =13 | date =20 February 1932 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/667597/william_sulzer_speaks_at_bahai_meeting/ | accessdate = 19 June 2014}}</ref>
Later during his stay in Washington, `Abdu'l-Bahá spoke at [[Bethel Literary and Historical Society]], the leading African-American institution of Washington DC.<ref>{{harvnb|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1912|pp=49–52}}</ref> The talk had been planned out by the end of March due to the work of Louis Gregory.<ref name="Gregory" /><ref>{{harvnb|Thomas|2006|pp=32–33}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Bahai Leader May Address Bethel Literary | newspaper = Washington Bee |pages=2, 4th column | publisher = | date = 30 March 1912 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84025891/1912-03-30/ed-1/seq-2/ | accessdate = 29 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140203094426/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84025891/1912-03-30/ed-1/seq-2/| archivedate = 3 February 2014}}</ref> While in Washington `Abdu'l-Bahá continued to speak from the Parson's home to individuals and groups.<ref>{{cite news| title = Persian Priest Attracts Society Women to the Cult of Bahaism; Followers kiss flowing robes of Abdul Baha at his Address to Leaders of Washington Smart Circles, in the ... | newspaper = Washington Post | page = 12 (3rd and 4th columns, registration required) | date = 26 April 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=5510298&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=9&currentPage=0&fpo=False | accessdate =30 April 2010}}</ref> A Methodist minister suggested some of his listeners should teach him Christianity, though also judged him sincere.<ref>{{cite news| title = Prayer for Abdul Baha; Methodists Hope he will "See LIght" and Go Home | newspaper = Washington Post | page = 2 (6th column, registration required | date = 29 April 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=5511301&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=3&currentPage=10&fpo=False | accessdate = 30 April 2010 }}</ref>
===Mid-West=== [[File:Willmette how.jpg|thumb|230px|right|Bahá'í House of Worship, [[Wilmette, Illinois]].]] `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in [[Chicago]] on 29 April,<ref name="smith" /> though later than anticipated as he had hoped to be in Chicago in time for the American Bahá'í national convention.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = 'Abdu'l-Bahá in Chicago |magazine= Bahá'í News | date = September 1977 |pages=2–8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | issue = 558 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140512094900/http://teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | archivedate = 12 May 2014 }}</ref> While in Chicago `Abdu'l-Bahá attended the last session of the newly founded Bahá'í Temple Unity, and laid the dedication stone of the [[Bahá'í House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)|Bahá'í House of Worship]] near Chicago.<ref>{{cite web | title = Abdu’l-Baha and the House of Worship | work = | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | date = 17 April 2008 | url = http://www.bahai.us/abdul-bahai-house-of-worship | accessdate = 27 March 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101228150849/http://www.bahai.us/abdul-bahai-house-of-worship| archivedate = 28 December 2010}}</ref>
[[Robert Sengstacke Abbott]], an African American lawyer and newspaper publisher, met `Abdu'l-Bahá when covering a talk of his during his stay in Chicago at [[Jane Addams]]' [[Hull House]].<ref name="door">[http://www.uga.edu/bahai/News/101095.html Robert S. Abbott and the Chicago Defender: A Door to the Masses] by Mark Perry, printed in the 10 October 1995 issue of the [[Michigan Chronicle]]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606005447/http://www.uga.edu/bahai/News/101095.html |date=6 June 2011 }}</ref> He would later become a Bahá'í in 1934.<ref>[[Roi Ottley|Ottley, Roi]]. The Lonely Warrior. United States of America: Henry Regnery Company, 1955. Print. 160.</ref> Also while `Abdu'l-Bahá was in Chicago, the [[NAACP]]'s print magazine ''[[The Crisis]]'' printed an article introducing the religion to their readers,<ref>{{cite journal| author = The Crisis Publishing Company, Inc.| editor-last = Du Bois| editor-first = W. E. Burghardt| editor2-last = MacLean| editor2-first = M. D.| title = The Fourth Annual Conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People| url = https://books.google.com/?id=G1oEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA1| accessdate = 2 April 2010| volume = 04| date = May 1912| publisher = National Association for the Advancement of Colored People| pages = 14–16| ref = harv| issue = 1| journal = The Crisis; A Record of the Darker Races }}</ref> and later in June noted `Abdu'l-Bahá's talk at their fourth national convention.<ref>{{harvnb|Morrison|1982|p=55,150}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| author = The Crisis Publishing Company, Inc.| editor-last = Du Bois| editor-first = W. E. Burghardt| editor2-last = MacLean| editor2-first = M. D.| title = The Fourth Annual Conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People| url = https://books.google.com/?id=H1oEAAAAMBAJ| accessdate = 4 February 2010| volume = 04| date = 4 June 1912| publisher = National Association for the Advancement of Colored People| page = 80| ref = harv| issue = 2| journal = The Crisis; A Record of the Darker Races }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| last = `Abdu'l-Bahá| authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá| editor-last = Du Bois| editor-first = W. E. Burghardt| editor2-last = MacLean| editor2-first = M. D.| title = The Brotherbood of Man| url = https://books.google.com/?id=H1oEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53| accessdate = 4 February 2010| volume = 04| date = 4 June 1912| publisher = National Association for the Advancement of Colored People| pages = 88–89| ref = harv| issue = 2| journal = The Crisis; A Record of the Darker Races }}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá left Chicago on 6 May and went to [[Cleveland]] where he stayed until the 7th. Though [[Saichiro Fujita]], one of the first Bahá'ís of Japanese descent, was living in Cleveland working for a Dr Barton-Peek, a female Bahá'í, he failed to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá as he came through. He was able to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá later during his further travels.<ref>{{harvnb|Sims|1989|pp=1–2}}</ref> In Cleveland `Abdu'l-Bahá spoke at his hotel twice and was interviewed by newspaper reporters.<ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=81–83}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Busta-Peck | first = Christopher | title = 'Abdu'l-Bahá and the Bahá'í Faith | work = Cleveland in Cuyahoga County, Ohio | publisher = HMdb.org | date = 16 April 2009 | url = http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=17950 | accessdate = 2 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121014032448/http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=17950 | archivedate = 14 October 2012 }}</ref> Among some who met `Abdu'l-Bahá in Cleveland included Louise Gregory,<ref>{{harvnb|Etter-Lewis|2006|pp=51–52}}</ref> and [[Alain Locke]].<ref>{{cite conference | last = Buck | first = Christopher | title = Alain Locke; "Race Amity" & the Bahá'í Faith | conference = Alain Lock Centenary Program | publisher = American Association of Rhodes Scholars, Howard University | date = 24 September 2007| location = Washington D.C. | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/29375758/Buck-Locke-Centenary | accessdate = 2 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121103005721/http://www.scribd.com/doc/29375758/Buck-Locke-Centenary | archivedate = 3 November 2012 }}</ref>
On 7 May `Abdu'l-Bahá went to [[Pittsburgh]] where a speaking engagement was arranged for him in early April through the efforts of [[Martha Root]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Leader of Bahaism is Coming to Pittsburgh| newspaper = The Gazette Times | page = 7 | date = 4 July 1912| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gLExAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U2YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2269,799616&hl=en | accessdate = 4 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="root">{{cite web | last = Francis | first = Richard | title = Martha Root - Herald of the Kingdom, Lioness at the Threshold | work = Biographies | publisher = Baha'i Library Online | year = 1998 | url = http://bahai-library.com/francis_root_biography | accessdate = 4 June 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130404201409/http://bahai-library.com/francis_root_biography | archivedate = 4 April 2013 }}</ref> He stayed in Pittsburgh for one day before going back to Washington D.C on 8 May 1912.
===Back to North East=== [[File:Mohonk Mountain House 2011 View of Mohonk Guest Rooms from One Hiking Trail FRD 3205.jpg|250px|right|thumb|[[Mohonk Mountain House]], a resort hotel located on the [[Shawangunk Ridge]]]] `Abdu'l-Bahá stayed in Washington DC from 8 to 11 May, when he then returned to the New York City area. On 12 May he visited [[Montclair, NJ]], and then on 14 May he went to northern [[New York (state)|New York state]] to [[Lake Mohonk]] where he addressed the [[Lake Mohonk Conference on International Arbitration]] and stayed at the [[Mohonk Mountain House]].<ref name="Mahmud pp. 100–103">{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=100–103}}</ref><ref name="Ives p. 196">{{harvnb|Ives|1983|p=196}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Parsons|1996|p=161}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title = Head of New Religion of Peace | newspaper = Atlanta Constitution| page = 7 | publisher = American Press Association | date = 30 May 1912 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=53&did=546265512&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1272903667 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="Harvard University">{{cite book| title = Report of the annual Lake Mohonk Conference on International Arbitration| url = https://books.google.com/?id=g2kNAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA42| year = 1912| publisher = Harvard University| location = Lake Mohonk| pages = 42–44 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Head of New religion Prominent at Lake Mohonk Conference | newspaper = The Lowerll Sun | page = 6 | date = 18 May 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=56076252&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=2&currentPage=0&fpo=False| accessdate = 30 April 2010}}</ref>
His talk was covered by many publications,<ref name="Lacroix " /><ref>{{cite journal| last = Elkinton| first = Joseph| title = The Mohonk Conference on Peace and International Arbitration of 1912| url = https://books.google.com/?id=jkErAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA379| accessdate = 27 March 2010| volume = 85| date = 30 May 1912| publisher = Edwin P. Sellew| page = 379| ref = harv| issue = 48| journal = The Friend; A Religious and Literary Journal }}</ref><ref>{{cite book| author = Free Religious Association (Boston, Mass.) Meeting| title = Proceedings at the 45th Annual meeting of the Free Religious Association| url = https://books.google.com/?id=GC4NAAAAYAAJ| year = 1912| publisher = Adams & Co.| pages = 84–90 }}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Spring|1944|p=161}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Bixby | first = James T. | title = What is Behaism? | jstor = 25119778| isbn = }}</ref> and began <blockquote>"When we consider history, we find that civilization is progressing, but in this century its progress cannot be compared with that of past centuries. This is the century of light and of bounty. In the past, the unity of patriotism, the unity of nations and religions was established; but in this century, the oneness of the world of humanity is established; hence this century is greater than the past."<ref name="Harvard University" /></blockquote>
In the rest of his talk he outlined a brief history of religious conflict, spoke about some of the [[Bahá'í teachings]] including the [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of humanity|oneness of humanity]], the [[Bahá'í Faith and science|complimentary role of religion and science]], the [[Bahá'í Faith and gender equality|equality of women and men]], the abolition of the extremes of wealth and poverty, and that humanity needs more than philosophy — that it needs the breadth of the [[Holy Spirit]]. A reverend heard his presentation and invited him and introduced him at a reception at another event on 28 May.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Foster| first = E | title = Address at Metropolitan Temple Reception, 7th Ave and 14th St, NY, May 28, 1912 | journal = Star of the West | volume = 03 | issue = 7 | pages = 14–15 | publisher = Bahá'í News Service | location = Chicago, USA | date = 28 April 1910 | url =http://www.bahai-education.org/star/ | editor-last = Windust | editor-first = Albert R | editor2-last = Buikema | editor2-first = Gertrude | accessdate = 28 March 2010 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111107020747/http://bahai-education.org:80/star/ | archivedate = 7 November 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Points toward Peace; Religious Unity will bring World Amity, says Persian Teacher | newspaper = New York Times | date = 29 May 1912 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/05/29/104897090.pdf| accessdate = 4 November 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216001137/https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/05/29/104897090.pdf| archivedate = 16 December 2013}}</ref> [[Elbert Hubbard]], an American writer, also noted `Abdu'l-Bahá's talk at the Mohonk conference.<ref>{{harvnb|Hubbard|1912|pp=21–40}}</ref> Samuel Chiles Mitchell, then [[List of Presidents of the University of South Carolina|President at the University of South Carolina]] was present and affected by his presentation.<ref>{{cite thesis | last =Venters, III| first =Louis E. | title =Most great reconstruction: The Baha'i Faith in Jim Crow South Carolina, 1898-1965 |publisher = Colleges of Arts and Sciences University of South Carolina | year = 2010 |url =http://bahai-library.com/venters_bahai_south_carolina | isbn =978-1-243-74175-2 <!-- UMI Number: 3402846 -->|pages=127–129 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20140406173608/http://bahai-library.com/venters_bahai_south_carolina | archivedate =6 April 2014 }}</ref> Through correspondence with Gregory, Gregory came to the view that Mitchell had repeated `Abdu'l-Bahá’s words "upon many platforms."
After the conference, `Abdu'l-Bahá returned to New York City, where he stayed until the 22nd, leaving to the [[Boston]] area for four days including a trip to [[Worcester, Massachusetts]] on the 23rd. On 26 May he returned to New York City, where he would remain for most of his time until 20 June. He took short trips to [[Fanwood, New Jersey]], from 31 May to 1 June, to [[Milford, Pennsylvania]], on 3 June, and to [[Philadelphia]] from 8 to 10 June, always returning to New York City.<ref name="smith" />
On 18 June `Abdu'l-Bahá hosted a meeting at the MacNutt's home for the purpose of being filmed and recorded. This film was the second time that `Abdu'l-Bahá was filmed,<ref group="nb">The first film was by a production company that asked if they could film him for few minutes to appear in a [[newsreel]] the first week he arrived He agreed over the objection of the Bahá'ís who felt the process was not socially proper. This first film was incorporated into a 1985 documentary by the BBC TV unit in 1985 called "The Quiet Revolution" as part of the "Everyman" TV series.</ref> and was done by Bahá'ís at the home of Howard MacNutt.<ref>[http://bahai-library.com/ives_stories_grace_ober Stories of Muriel Ives Newhall Barrow, Grace Robarts Ober] by Muriel Ives Barrow Newhall, 1998 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130404155629/http://bahai-library.com/ives_stories_grace_ober |date=4 April 2013 }}</ref> The film recorded at the MacNutt residence was released as a short movie called "Servant of Glory".<ref name="Lacroix " /><ref name="Mahmud p. 42">{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|p=42}}</ref>
Over several days starting on 1 June `Abdu'l-Bahá sat for a life-sized portrait by [[Juliet Thompson]].<ref name="Lacroix " /><ref>{{cite magazine | title = Sixtieth Anniversary of 'Abdu'l-Bahá's Travels to the Western World |magazine= Bahá'í News | date = November 1971 | page =7 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | issue = 488 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140512094900/http://teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | archivedate = 12 May 2014 }}</ref> During that time Thompson witnessed [[Lua Getsinger]] given the task of conveying `Abdu'l-Bahá's message that New York was the ''City of the Covenant'';<ref>{{cite magazine | title = New York Sites Visited by 'Abdu'l·Baha |magazine= Bahá'í News | date = June 1966 | page =8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | issue = 423 | ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140512094900/http://teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | archivedate = 12 May 2014 }}</ref> when the group moved into the rest of the house Getsinger made the announcement.
Later in the month, `Abdu'l-Bahá visited [[Montclair, New Jersey]] from 20 to 25 June,<ref>{{cite news| title = Jersey's New Resident; Abdul Pasha, Persian Religious Leadder, to Live in Montclair | newspaper = The New Brunswick Times | page = 7 (registration required) | date = 3 June 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=155063089&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0&fpo=False | accessdate = 30 April 2010}}</ref> coming back to New York until 29 June. On 29 and 30 June he visited West Englewood, NJ which is now [[Teaneck, New Jersey|Teaneck]] and attended a ''Unity Feast'' similar to a [[Nineteen Day Feast]]<ref>{{harvnb|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1912|pp=213–215}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Thompson|Gail|1983|pp=322–25}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|pp=149–151}}</ref> where Bahá'ís, Jews, Muslims, Christians, Caucasians, African-Americans, and Persians attended.<ref name="Mahmud p. 42" /><ref>{{harvnb|Johnston|1975|p=10,317}}</ref> Among those that attended the event was [[Martha Root]].<ref name="root" /> For her it was a high point in her life and has since been commemorized as `Abdu'l-Bahá's "Souvenir Picnic".<ref>{{harvnb|Garis|1983|p=53}}</ref> It is at this event that [[Lua Getsinger]] intentionally walked through poison ivy hoping to make her incapable of leaving the presence of `Abdu'l-Bahá when he asked her to travel ahead of him to California.<ref name="Thompson 1983" /><ref>{{harvnb|Metelmann|1997|pp=159–161}}</ref> Today the property is known as the Wilhelm Bahá'í Properties.<ref name="Lacroix " />
His further travels took him to [[Morristown, New Jersey]] on 30 June and he then went back to New York for a nearly a month from 30 June to 23 July, with a sojourn in West Englewood, NJ on 14 July. Starting on 23 June `Abdu'l-Bahá went to New England on his way to Canada in late August. He stayed in Boston for 23 and 24 July, and then went to the summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Parsons in [[Dublin, New Hampshire]] from 24 July to 16 Aug.<ref>{{harvnb|Parsons|1996|p=69}}</ref> He then went to [[Eliot, Maine]] from 16 to 23 Aug, where he stayed in [[Green Acre]] which was then a conference facility, and which since has become a Bahá'í school.<ref>{{harvnb|Parsons|1996|pp=113–120}}</ref><ref>harvnb|Zarqáni|1998|p=209-220</ref> His final destination in New England was [[Malden, Massachusetts]] where he stayed from 23 to 29 August.<ref name="smith" />
===Trip to Canada=== `Abdu'l-Bahá had mentioned an intention of visiting [[Montreal]] as early as February 1912 and in August a phone number was listed for inquirers to arrange appointments for his visit there. He left to Boston and then rode to Montreal where he arrived near midnight on 30 August 1912 at the [[Windsor Station (Montreal)|Windsor train station]] on [[Peel Street, Montreal|Peel Street]] and was greeted by [[William Sutherland Maxwell]]. He would stay in Montreal until 9 September. On his first day in the city he was visited by Frederick Robertson Griffin who would later lead the [[First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia]]. Later that morning he visited a friend of the Maxwell's who had a sick baby. In the afternoon he took a car ride around Montreal. That evening a reception was held including a local socialist leader. The next day he spoke at a Unitarian church on [[Sherbrooke Street]]. [[Anne Savage (artist)|Anne Savage]] recorded that she had sought him out but uncharacteristically was shy upon seeing him. He took up residence in the [[Windsor Hotel (Montreal)|Windsor Hotel]]. The next day [[William Peterson (academic)|William Peterson]], then Principal of [[McGill University]] visited him. After a day of meeting individuals he took an afternoon excursion on his own possibly to the francophone part of the city and back. That evening he spoke to a socialist meeting addressing "The Economic Happiness of the Human Race" — that we are as one family and should care for each other, not to have absolute equality but to have a firm minimum even for the poorest, to note foremost the position of the farmer, and a [[progressive tax]] system.<ref>{{cite news | title = Apostle of Peace meets Socialists | newspaper = The Montreal Gazette | page = 2 | date = 4 September 1912 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oBYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9oQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5135,250164&hl=en | accessdate = 4 November 2010}}</ref> The next day he rode the [[Mountain Elevator of Montreal]] The next day [[Paul Bruchési]] Archbishop of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Montreal]] visited him and later he spoke at the [[Saint James United Church (Montreal)|Saint James United Church]]; his talk outlined a comprehensive review of the [[Bahá'í teachings]]. Afterwards he said:<blockquote>I find these two great American nations highly capable and advanced in all that appertains to progress and civilization. These governments are fair and equitable. The motives and purposes of these people are lofty and inspiring. Therefore, it is my hope that these revered nations may become prominent factors in the establishment of international peace and the oneness of the world of humanity; that they may lay the foundations of equality and spiritual brotherhood among mankind; that they may manifest the highest virtues of the human world, revere the divine lights of the Prophets of God and establish the reality of unity so necessary today in the affairs of nations. I pray that the nations of the East and West shall become one flock under the care and guidance of the divine Shepherd. Verily, this is the bestowal of God and the greatest honor {{sic}} of man. This is the glory of humanity. This is the good pleasure of God. I ask God for this with a contrite heart.<ref>[http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PUP/pup-102.html PUP 312–319] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128205709/http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PUP/pup-102.html |date=28 November 2012 }}</ref></blockquote>
`Abdu'l-Bahá's visit to Montreal provided notable newspaper coverage; on the night of his arrival the editor of the ''[[Montreal Daily Star]]'' met with him and that newspaper along with [[The Montreal Gazette]], ''Montreal Standard'', [[Le Devoir]] and [[La Presse (Canada)|La Presse]] among others reported on `Abdu'l-Bahá's activities.<ref name="vanderHoonaard56">{{harvnb|Van den Hoonaard|1996|pp=56–68}}</ref><ref name="b_p256">{{harvnb|Balyuzi|2001|p=256}}</ref> The headlines in those papers included "Persian Teacher to Preach Peace", "Racialism Wrong, Says Eastern Sage, Strife and War Caused by Religious and National Prejudices", and "Apostle of Peace Meets Socialists, Abdul Baha's Novel Scheme for Distribution of Surplus Wealth."<ref name="b_p256" /> The ''Montreal Standard'', which was distributed across Canada, took so much interest that it republished the articles a week later; the Gazette published six articles and Montreal's largest French language newspaper published two articles about him.<ref name="vanderHoonaard56" /> The ''Harbor Grace Standard'' newspaper, of [[Harbour Grace]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], printed a story summarizing several of his talks and trips.<ref>{{cite news | title = Persian Peace Prophet gives Message to Canada through the Standard | newspaper = The Harbor Grace Standard | date = 7 September 1912 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hYkcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xGIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4009,6137749&hl=en| page = 17| accessdate = 4 November 2010}}</ref> After he left the country, the ''Winnipeg Free Press'' highlighted his position on the equality of women and men.<ref>{{cite news | title = Message of the Great Persian Reformer | newspaper = Winnipeg Free Press | location = Winnipeg, Manitoba | page = 9, column 3 (registration required) | date = 19 September 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=41607619&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=28&currentPage=30&fpo=False | accessdate = 24 April 2010}}</ref> All together some accounts of his talks and trips would reach 440,000 in French and English coverage.<ref name="Vanden">{{harvnb|Van den Hoonaard|1996|pp=43–63}}</ref> He travelled through several villages on the way back to the States.<ref>A portion of Van den Hoonaard's book is posted online along with rare pictures at {{cite web | title = The Bahá’í Faith comes to Hamilton | work = | publisher = The Baha'i Community of [[Hamilton, Ontario]], Canada | date = | url = http://www.bahaihamilton.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3&Itemid=9| accessdate = 31 August 2016| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131215233009/http://www.bahaihamilton.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3&Itemid=9| archivedate = 15 December 2013}}</ref>
===Travel to the West coast=== `Abdu'l-Bahá left Canada and started his travel to the American West coast stopping in multiple places in the country during his travels. From 9 September through 12th he stayed in [[Buffalo, New York]], where he made a fleeting visit to [[Niagara Falls]] on 12 September.<ref name="MacEoin">{{cite web | last = MacEoin | first = Denis | author2 = Collins, William | title = Memorials (Listings)| work = The Babi and Baha'i Religions: An Annotated Bibliography | publisher = Greenwood Press's ongoing series of Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies | url = http://bahai-library.com/books/biblio/memorials.html | accessdate = 2 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130407182102/http://bahai-library.com/books/biblio/memorials.html | archivedate = 7 April 2013 }}</ref> He then travelled to [[Chicago]] (12–15 September), [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]] (15–16 September), back to Chicago on 16 September, and then to [[Minneapolis]] where he stayed from 16 to 21 September.<!-- local newspapers were online once [https://web.archive.org/web/20071210175528/http://www.mndaily.com/archive/index.php?year=1912] but pulled for OCR scanning but they've not yet posted 1912 - [http://www.mndaily.com/archives/pdfs/1912 PDF Archives: 1912 | mndaily.com - The Minnesota Daily] -->
His further travels took him to [[Omaha, Nebraska]] (21 September), [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] (23 September), [[Denver]], Colorado ( 24–27 September), [[Glenwood Springs, Colorado]] (28 September), and [[Salt Lake City]] (29–30 September).<ref>{{cite news | title = Come to Lecture on Bahai Religion | newspaper = Salt Lake Tribune| location = Salt Lake City |pages=5, 4th column (registration required)| date = 30 September 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=95000518&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=60&fpo=False | accessdate = 24 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Come to Lecture on Bahai Religion | newspaper = The Evening Standard | location = Ogden Utah |pages=14, 4th column (registration required)| publisher = | date = 30 September 1912 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=54190952&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=9&currentPage=50&fpo=False |accessdate = 24 April 2010}}</ref> In Salt Lake City, `Abdu'l-Bahá, accompanied by his translators, [[Saichiro Fujita]] and others attended the Utah State Fair and visited the [[Mormon Tabernacle]]. During the Mormon's annual convention, at the steps of the Temple, he was reported to have said: "They built me a temple but they will not let me in!" He left the next day and travelled by railcar to San Francisco, on what was then the Central Pacific Railroad, through Reno. Traveling all day through Nevada on its way to California, the train made regular stops but there's no record of `Abdu'l-Bahá disembarking until his arrival in San Francisco. While traversing the Sierra Nevada, he made a reference to observing the snow sheds at [[Donner Pass]] and the struggle of the pioneering members of the [[Donner Party]].
===California=== `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in [[San Francisco]] on 4 October.<ref>{{cite journal| first = Frances Orr | last = Allen | title = 'Abdu'l-Bahá in San Francisco, California | journal = Star of the West | volume = 3 | issue = 12 | date = 16 October 1912 | page = 9| ref = harv }}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Brown|1980|p=34}}</ref> During his visit to California he mostly stayed in [[Bay Area]] including from 4–13 October, 16–18 October, 21–25 October with shorter trips to [[Pleasanton, California|Pleasanton]] from 13 to 16 October, to [[Los Angeles]] from 18–21 October and to [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] from 25–26 October While in San Francisco, `Abdu'l-Bahá spoke at [[Stanford University]] on 8 October, and at Temple Emmanuel-El on 12 October.
When `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in Los Angeles he went to the [[Hotel Lankershim]], where he would reside during he stay, and where he would later give a talk.<ref>{{cite news| title = Foreign Tongue Soothes; Bahaistic Leader Gives Advice and Comfort through Interpreter' Followers Quekk Threatened Revolt | newspaper = Los Angeles Times | page = 110 | date = 21 October 1912 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=61&did=348420242&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1272904244 | accessdate = 3 May 2010 }}</ref><ref group="nb">The hotel was located at Broadway and 7th. More information about the hotel can be found at {{cite web | last = Dickerson | first = Brent C. | title = A Visit to Old Los Angeles | work = Indexes of Grab-Bag Essays and Old Los Angeles Episodes | date = | url = http://www.csulb.edu/~odinthor/socal7.html| accessdate = 3 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130501190312/http://www.csulb.edu/~odinthor/socal7.html| archivedate = 1 May 2013}}. The hotel was sold in 1919 and the company that owned it dissolved in 1933 {{cite web| last = Thompson | first = Daniella | title = The Shattuck Hotel: Berkeley’s Once and Future Jewel? | work = East Bay: Then and Now | publisher = Berkely Landmarks | date = | url = http://berkeleyheritage.com/berkeley_landmarks/shattuck_hotel.html| accessdate = 3 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130124065046/http://berkeleyheritage.com/berkeley_landmarks/shattuck_hotel.html| archivedate = 24 January 2013}}</ref> On his first full day in Los Angeles `Abdu'l-Bahá, along with twenty-five other Bahá'ís, visited [[Thornton Chase|Thornton Chase's]] grave on 19 October. Thornton Chase was the first American Bahá'í, and he had only recently moved to Los Angeles and helped form the first [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] in the city.<ref>{{cite web | last = Dobbs | first = Randolph | title = Los Angeles Baha'i community turns 100 | work = Commemorations | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United States | date = 8 January 2010 | url = http://www.bahai.us/LA_100_anniversary | accessdate = 4 November 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101228143843/http://www.bahai.us/LA_100_anniversary | archivedate = 28 December 2010 }}</ref> `Abdu'l-Bahá was eager to meet Thornton Chase, but Chase died on the evening of 30 September shortly before `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in California on 4 October. `Abdu'l-Bahá designated Chase's grave a place of pilgrimage, and revealed a tablet of visitation, which is a prayer to say in remembrance of a person, and decreed that his death be commemorated annually.<ref name="StockmanChase">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Stockman|first= Robert H. |encyclopedia= Bahá’í Encyclopedia Project |title= Chase, Thornton (1847-1912) |year= 2009 |publisher= National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá’ís of the United States |location= Evanston, IL |url= http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?view=article&catid=37%3Abiography&id=46%3Achase-thornton-18471912&option=com_content&Itemid=74 | ref = harv |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140222175306/http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?view=article&catid=37%3Abiography&id=46%3Achase-thornton-18471912&option=com_content&Itemid=74 |archivedate= 22 February 2014 }}</ref>
===Back across America=== After his visit to California, `Abdu'l-Bahá started his trip back to the East coast. On his way back he stopped in [[Denver]] (28–29 October), [[Chicago]] (31 October – 3 November) and [[Cincinnati]] (5–6 November) before arriving in [[Washington, D.C.]] on 6 November. In Washington he was invited to speak to the [[Washington Hebrew Congregation]] at their temple on 9 November.<ref>{{cite news| title = Appeals to Jewish Hearers; Abdul Baha Addresses Washington Hebrew Congregation | newspaper = The Washington Post | page = 3 (registration required) | date = 9 November 1912 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=62&did=242972252&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1272904244 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}}</ref>
Later on 11 November, he travelled to [[Baltimore]], where his arrival was anticipated from early April,<ref>{{cite news | title = Abdul Baha Within Week; Persian Philosopher will Speak in this City | newspaper =The Baltimore Sun | page = 8 (requires registration) | date = 15 April 1912 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=32&did=1747701832&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1272901645 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}}</ref> and he spoke at a Unitarian church saying in part that "the world looked to America as the leader in the world-wide peace movement" and "not being a rival of any other power and not considering colonization schemes or conquests, made it an ideal country to lead the movement."<ref>{{cite news | title = Women Kis His Hand; Persian Advoate of Human Brother is Venerated | newspaper = The Baltimore Sun | page = 9 (registration required) | date = 12 November 1912 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=65&did=1761530532&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1272904244 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Abdul Baha here Tomorrow; Persian Philosopher Expected at Unitarian Church | newspaper = The Baltimore Sun | page = 12 (registration required) | date = 10 November 1912 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=63&did=1868708522&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1272904244 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}}</ref> On the same day he travelled to [[Philadelphia]], and the next day on 12 November he arrived back to [[New York City|New York]] where he stayed until he would leave back to Europe 5 December. During his stay in New York `Abdu'l-Bahá addressed a suffragette group elaborating on the equality of women and men.<ref>{{cite news | title = Minervas hear A Baha; Persian Sage Compliments 'Em on their "Radiant Faces" | newspaper = New-York Tribune| page = 11 | date = 26 November 1912 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-11-26/ed-1/seq-11/| accessdate = 16 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121006091901/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-11-26/ed-1/seq-11/| archivedate = 6 October 2012}}</ref>
On 5 December `Abdu'l-Bahá left New York, sailing for [[Liverpool]] on the [[RMS Celtic (1901)|RMS Celtic]].<ref name="gpb281">{{harvnb|Effendi|1979|p=281}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Ives|1983|pp=211–227}}</ref>
==Second trip to Europe== `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in [[Liverpool]] on 13 December,<ref>{{harvnb|Balyuzi|2001|p=343}}</ref> and over the next six months he visited Britain, France, Austria-Hungary, and Germany before finally returning to [[Egypt]] on 12 June 1913.<ref name="b_end" />
Several memoirs cover this period.<ref group="nb">Transcripts of many talks given by `Abdu'l-Bahá in the US and Canada can be found in:
* {{cite book | last = `Abdu'l-Bahá | first = | title = `Abdu'l-Bahá in London; Addresses & Notes of Conversations | publisher = UK Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year = 1987 | origyear = 1912 | url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/ABL/ | isbn = 978-0-900125-89-8| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131008230422/http://reference.bahai.org:80/en/t/ab/ABL/| archivedate = 8 October 2013}}
Other memoirs covering the period include:
* {{cite book| last = Sohrab | first = Ahmad | editor = David Merrick | title = Abdu'l-Bahá in the UK 1913; the Diary of Ahmad Sohrab; 5 Dec 1912 – 21 Jan 1913 (Draft) | publisher = David Merrick | date = | page = 250 | url = http://paintdrawer.co.uk/david/folders/spirituality/bahai/abdulbaha/sohrab-diary-uk-1913.pdf | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180131223409/http://paintdrawer.co.uk/david/folders/spirituality/bahai/abdulbaha/sohrab-diary-uk-1913.pdf | archivedate = 31 January 2018 }} * {{cite book| last = Blomfield| first = Lady| title = The Chosen Highway| url = http://bahai-library.com/blomfield_chosen_highway| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140330191122/http://bahai-library.com/blomfield_chosen_highway| archivedate = 30 March 2014| origyear = 1956| year = 1975| publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust| location = London, UK| isbn = 978-0-87743-015-5| pages = 147–187; Part III (`Abdu'l–Bahá), Chapters ''`Abdu'l–Baha in London'' and ''`Abdu'l–Baha in Paris'' }} * {{cite book| last = Gollmer| first = Werner| title = `Abdu'l-Baha in Germany| url = https://books.google.com/?id=lFAptwAACAAJ| year = 1988| publisher = Baháʼ í-Verl.| isbn = 978-3-87037-215-6 }} * {{cite book| last = Khursheed| first = Anjam| title = The Seven Candles of Unity; The Story of `Abdu'l-Bahá in Edinburgh| year = 1991| publisher = Baha'i Publishing Trust of the UK| location = London, UK| isbn = 978-1-870989-12-1| page = 246 }} * {{cite book| last = Sohrab | first = Ahmad | editor = David Merrick | title = Abdu'l-Bahá in Edinburgh; The Diary of Ahmad Sohrab; 6 Jan 1913 – 10 Jan 1913 | publisher = David Merrick | date = | url = http://www.paintdrawer.co.uk/david/folders/Spirituality/001=Bahai/Sohrab%20Diary%20Edinburgh.pdf | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131019115450/http://www.paintdrawer.co.uk/david/folders/Spirituality/001=Bahai/Sohrab%20Diary%20Edinburgh.pdf| archivedate = 19 October 2013}} * {{cite web | title = Abdu'l-Bahá's Visit to Edinburgh 1913 | work = based on ''Sohrab's Diary and The Seven Candles of Unity'' | date = 22 June 2007 | url =http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/history-visit.pdf| accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6HhM4TJcA?url=http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/history-visit.pdf| archivedate = 27 June 2013}}</ref>
===Great Britain=== After his arrival in Liverpool `Abdu'l-Bahá stayed in the city for three days before going to [[London]] by train on 16 December. He stayed in London until 6 January 1913 and during his stay there he gave multiple talks. In one of his talks on 2 January he spoke about women's suffrage to the [[Women's Freedom League]] — part of his address, and the accompanying print coverage of his talk, noted the examples of [[Táhirih]], [[Mary Magdalene]], and Queen [[Zenobia]] to the organization.<ref>{{cite news | title = The Equality of Woman. Abdul Baha to Lecture to a W.F.L. Meeting | newspaper = The Vote | page = 7 | date = 3 January 1913 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iOI6AAAAIBAJ&sjid=6ikMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2751,9282026&hl=en | accessdate = 4 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = (two stories) Towards Unity & An Eastern Prophet's Message: Abdul Baha says: "There is no distinction: Men and Women are Equal | newspaper = The Vote | pages = 180–182 | date = 10 January 1913 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ieI6AAAAIBAJ&sjid=6ikMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5298,9322493&hl=en| accessdate = 4 April 2010}}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá left London by the [[Euston railway station|Euston Station]] at 10am and arrived in [[Edinburgh]] at 6.15pm where he was met by Jane Elizabeth Whyte, a notable Scottish Bahá'í and wife of [[Alexander Whyte]], and others.<ref>{{cite web | title = Printable One-Page Timeline | work = Abdu'l-Bahá's Visit to Edinburgh 1913 | publisher = Edinburgh Baha'i Community | date = 22 June 2007 | url =http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/history-visit.pdf | accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120302023335/http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/history-visit.pdf | archivedate = 2 March 2012 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | title = Take the Visual Tour | work = Abdu'l-Bahá's Visit to Edinburgh 1913 | publisher = Edinburgh Baha'i Community | date = 22 June 2007 | url = http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/visit-abdul-baha.htm | accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120709032743/http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk:80/history/visit-abdul-baha.htm | archivedate = 9 July 2012 }}</ref> While in Edinburgh he and his associates stayed at the Georgian House of #7 [[Charlotte Square]]. On 7 January `Abdu'l-Bahá visited the [[Outlook Tower]], and then went on a driving tour of some of Edinburgh and the nearby countryside;<ref>{{cite web | title = Take the Visual Tour | work = `Abdu'l-Bahá's Visit to Edinburgh 1913 | publisher = Edinburgh Baha'i Community | date = 22 June 2007 | url =http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/visit-abdul-baha.htm | accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120709032743/http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk:80/history/visit-abdul-baha.htm | archivedate = 9 July 2012 }}</ref> later in the afternoon he met with students of the [[University of Edinburgh]] in the library of 7 Charlotte Sq, followed by a talk to the Edinburgh [[Esperanto]] Society in the Freemason's Hall. The meeting in the library was run by [[Alexander Whyte]] who said "Dear and honoured Sir, I have had many meetings in this house, but never have I seen such a meeting It reminds me of what St. Paul said, ' God hath made of one blood all nations of men,' and of what our Lord said, ' They shall come from the East and the West, from the North and the South, and shall sit down in the Kingdom of God.'"<ref>{{harvnb|Barbour|1923|p=554}}</ref>
