`Abdu'l-Bahá's stay in Edinburgh was covered by [[The Scotsman]] newspaper.<ref>{{cite news | title = International Amity, Meetings of Edinburg Citizens to Greet... | newspaper = The Scotsman |page=1 (registration required)| date = 4 January 1913 | url =http://archive.scotsman.com/search.cfm?keywords=abdul+baha&match=allWords&exclusions=&yearFrom=1817&monthFrom=1&dayFrom=1&yearTo=1915&monthTo=12&dayTo=31&sort=Score%2Cdesc&entityType=all| accessdate = 4 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Abdul Baha in Edinburgh | newspaper = The Scotsman |page=10 (registration required)| date = 8 January 1913 | url =http://archive.scotsman.com/search.cfm?keywords=abdul+baha&match=allWords&exclusions=&yearFrom=1817&monthFrom=1&dayFrom=1&yearTo=1915&monthTo=12&dayTo=31&sort=Score%2Cdesc&entityType=all| accessdate = 4 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Abdul Baha in Edinburgh | newspaper = The Scotsman |page=11 (registration required)| date = 9 January 1913 | url =http://archive.scotsman.com/search.cfm?keywords=abdul+baha&match=allWords&exclusions=&yearFrom=1817&monthFrom=1&dayFrom=1&yearTo=1915&monthTo=12&dayTo=31&sort=Score%2Cdesc&entityType=all| accessdate = 4 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = "Bahaism" and Christianity | newspaper = The Scotsman |page=10 (registration required)| date = 13 January 1913 | url =http://archive.scotsman.com/search.cfm?keywords=abdul+baha&match=allWords&exclusions=&yearFrom=1817&monthFrom=1&dayFrom=1&yearTo=1915&monthTo=12&dayTo=31&sort=Score%2Cdesc&entityType=all| accessdate = 4 April 2010}}</ref> The newspaper coverage lead to a stream of visitors and speaking engagements on 8 Jan; he spoke at the [[Edinburgh College of Art]], and the North Canongate School.<ref group="nb">The school was closed and renamed the "Canongate Venture"{{cite web | title = The Canongate Venture | work = | publisher = Canongate Community Forum | date = 13 August 1987 | url =http://www.eh8.org.uk/the_canongate_venture | accessdate = 4 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120303053421/http://www.eh8.org.uk/the_canongate_venture| archivedate = 3 March 2012}} scheduled for demolition in 2008 {{cite web | title = Report on the Canongate Project, May – June 2008 | work = | publisher = Canongate Community Forum | year = 2008 | url =http://www.eh8.org.uk/sites/eh8.org.uk/files/canongate-final-report-web_0.pdf| accessdate = 4 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120303053425/http://www.eh8.org.uk/sites/eh8.org.uk/files/canongate-final-report-web_0.pdf| archivedate = 3 March 2012}} but which survived at least to 2010 {{cite web | title =A New Canongate Venture | work = | publisher = Edinburgh Old Town Development Trust | year = 2010 | url = http://eotdt.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70&Itemid=80 | accessdate = 4 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120306085445/http://eotdt.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70&Itemid=80| archivedate = 6 March 2012}}</ref> Later in the evening he spoke at Rainy Hall, which is part of [[New College, Edinburgh|New College]], which was followed by a viewing of [[Handel's Messiah]] in [[St Giles' Cathedral]]. Visitors again came on the 9th, and in the evening he gave a talk with the Theosophical society hosted by [[David Graham Pole]]. That night and or early the next morning `Abdu'l-Bahá wrote a letter to [[Andrew Carnegie]].<ref>[http://reference.bahai.org/search?max=10&first=1&query=carnegie&idxname%5B%5D=en-UD Unfolding Destiny] mentions tablet</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Abdu'l-Bahá's Visit to Edinburgh 1913 | work = | publisher = | date = 22 June 2007 | url =http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/history-visit.pdf| accessdate = 10 January 2010| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6HhM4TJcA?url=http://www.edin-bahai.org.uk/history/history-visit.pdf| archivedate = 27 June 2013}}</ref> The letter commented on reading [[The Gospel of Wealth]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Carnegie | first = Andrew | authorlink = Andrew Carnegie | title = The Gospel of Wealth and other Timely Essays (annotated with Bahá'í references) | work = | publisher = | date = | url =http://www.webpal.org/SAFE/aaareconstruction/philosophical/carnegie/content.htm| accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131215235838/http://www.webpal.org/SAFE/aaareconstruction/philosophical/carnegie/content.htm| archivedate = 15 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Abdul Baha's Tribute to Mr. Carnegie; Famous Persian Prophet Praises the "Gospel of Wealth" and Tells When the Rich May Give to the Poor. | newspaper = New York Times | pages = SM12, Magazine Section 6 | publisher = | date = 9 February 1913 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9903E3DC133BE633A2575AC0A9649C946296D6CF | accessdate = 4 April 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216001152/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9903E3DC133BE633A2575AC0A9649C946296D6CF| archivedate = 16 December 2013}}</ref> `Abdu'l-Bahá again sent a letter to Carnegie in 1915.<ref>{{cite news | title = Carnegie Exalted by Bahaist Leader; Abdul Baha Abbas Sends Letter from Syria Extolling His Efforts for Peace| newspaper = New York Times | date = 5 September 1915| url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/09/05/301813232.pdf|accessdate = 1 May 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216001134/https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/09/05/301813232.pdf| archivedate = 16 December 2013}}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá and his associates leave Edinburgh mid-morning on the 10th, and went back to London until the 15th. Then he was in [[Bristol]] on 15 and 16 January, coming back to London where he stayed until the 21st, except for a trip to [[Woking]] on the 18th.<ref name="smith" />
===Continental Europe=== [[File:Abdul-baha in Paris.jpg|thumb|`Abdu'l-Bahá, near the [[Eiffel Tower]] in Paris, 1913.]] `Abdu'l-Bahá's arrived in Paris on 22 January; the visit which was his second to the city last for a couple months. During his stay in the city he continued his public talks, as well as with meeting Bahá'ís, including locals, those from Germany, and those who had come from the East specifically to meet with him. During his stay in Paris, `Abdu'l-Bahá's stayed at an apartment at 30 Rue St Didier which was rented for him by [[Hippolyte Dreyfus-Barney]].<ref name="balyuzi373">{{harvnb|Balyuzi|2001|pp=373–379}}</ref>
Some of the notables that `Abdu'l-Bahá met while in Paris include the Persian minister in Paris, several prominent Ottomans from the previous regime, professor 'Inayatu'llah Khan, and [[E.G. Browne]].<ref name="balyuzi373" /> He also gave a talk on the evening of the 12th to the [[Esperanto|Esperantists]], and on the next evening gave a talk to the Theosophists at the Hotel Moderne. He had met with a group of Pairs professors and theological students at Pasteur Henri Monneir's Theological Seminary; Pasteur Monnier was a distinguished Protestant theologian, vice-president of the [[Protestant Federation of France]] and professor of Protestant theology in Paris.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Fazel | first = Seena | title = 'Abdu'l-Bahá on Christ and Christianity | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 03 | issue = 1 | publisher = | year = 1993 | url = http://bahai-library.com/fazel_abdulbaha_christ_christianity | accessdate = 3 July 2010| ref = harv | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140404124851/http://bahai-library.com/fazel_abdulbaha_christ_christianity | archivedate = 4 April 2014 }}</ref> Around a week later, on the 21st, `Abdu'l-Bahá spoke at the [[Salle de Troyes]] which was organized by L'Alliance Spiritualiste.<ref name="balyuzi373" /> On 30 March, `Abdu'l-Bahá left Paris toward [[Stuttgart]].
He visited Germany for 8 days in 1913, including visiting Stuttgart, [[Esslingen am Neckar|Esslingen]] and [[Bad Mergentheim]].<ref name="b_end" /> During this visit he spoke to a youth group as well as a gathering of [[Esperantists]].<ref>{{harvnb|Effendi|1979|pp=286–87}}</ref> `Abdu'l-Bahá left Stuttgart to go to [[Budapest]], and on his way he changed trains in [[Vienna]], where a number of Iranian Bahá'ís were waiting for him.<ref name="balyuzi383">{{harvnb|Balyuzi|2001|pp=383–387}}</ref> He spoke to them while he was waiting for the train to Budapest. In Budapest `Abdu'l-Bahá met with a number of well known social leaders including academics and leaders of peace movements including Turks, Arabs, Jews and Catholics. See the [[Bahá'í Faith in Hungary#Before WWI|Bahá'í Faith in Hungary]]. He also met with the [[Theosophical Society]], and the Turkish Association. On 11 April he spoke at the hall of the old building of parliament, and on the next day he spoke to some visitors who included the president of the [[Turanian Society]].<ref name="balyuzi383" /> `Abdu'l-Bahá was supposed to leave to Vienna on the 15th, but because of a cold he did not travel to Vienna until 18 April.<ref name="balyuzi383" /><ref>{{cite web|title=A Draft Summary of the History and International Character of the Hungarian Bahá’í Community|url=http://www.bahai.hu/english/draft-summary-history-international-character-hungarian-bahai-community/|publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Hungary. 2011.|accessdate=26 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105101659/http://www.bahai.hu/english/draft-summary-history-international-character-hungarian-bahai-community/|archivedate=5 November 2013}}</ref> In Vienna `Abdu'l-Bahá met with the Persian minister, the Turkish Ambassador in multiple occasions, and spoke with Theosophists on three separate days. He also met with [[Bertha von Suttner]], who was the first woman to win the [[Nobel Peace Prize]].<ref name="balyuzi383" /> He left Vienna on the 24th, and went back to Stuttgart where he arrived early on 25 April 1913. During his week in Stuttgart, he mostly stayed at his hotel due to a lingering cold, but he did give a talk at a museum, as well as receiving guests at his room.<ref name="balyuzi388">{{harvnb|Balyuzi|2001|pp=388–401}}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá left Stuttgart on 1 May, arriving in Paris on the 2nd for his third stay in the French capital; he stayed in Paris until 12 June.<ref name="balyuzi388" /> Because his travels had led to reduced physical strength, `Abdu'l-Bahá was largely unable to go to meetings held in Bahá'í homes during his final stay in Paris, but he did hold meetings and talks at his hotel. He also met again with Turkish and Persian ministers. On June 6h, [[Ahmed Izzet Pasha]], the former grand vizier of the [[Ottoman Empire]], gave a dinner party for `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref name="balyuzi388" /> `Abdu'l-Bahá gave his final farewell at the Paris train station, when he boarded a train for [[Marseilles]] on 12 June. He stayed in Marseilles for one night before boarding the [[Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company|P & O]] steamer Himalaya early the next morning on 13 June. The steamer landed in [[Port Said]] in Egypt on 17 June 1913.<ref name="balyuzi388" />
===Return to Egypt=== When `Abdu'l-Bahá returned to Egypt, he decided not to immediately go back to [[Haifa]]. He stayed in Port Said until 11 July, and during his time there he met with many Bahá'ís, who had come to visit him from Haifa, and local Muslims and Christians.<ref name="balyuzi388" /> Because of bad weather conditions, `Abdu'l-Bahá moved to [[Ismailia]], but there he contracted a fever and only attended his mail during his week there. Thinking that the humid conditions in [[Alexandria]] would be better for his health, `Abdu'l-Bahá travelled on 17 July to a Ramleh, a suburb of Alexandria. On 1 August, his grandson [[Shoghi Effendi]], his sister [[Bahiyyih Khánum]] and his eldest daughter came to visit him from Haifa.<ref name="balyuzi388" /> Later during his stay he again met with [[Abbas II of Egypt]], the [[Khedive]] of Egypt. Finally on 2 December he boarded a [[Lloyd Triestino]] boat, and headed for Haifa with stops in Port Said and [[Jaffa]]. He landed in Haifa in the early afternoon of 5 December 1913.<ref name="balyuzi388" />
